case_vignette: A 71-YEAR-OLD MAN COMES TO THE PHYSICIAN FOR A HEALTH MAINTENANCE EXAMINATION. ASIDE FROM OCCASIONAL LOWER BACK PAIN IN THE LAST COUPLE OF YEARS, HE FEELS WELL. HE HAD A RIGHT-SIDED MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION 4 YEARS AGO. CURRENTLY, HE HAS NO SHORTNESS OF BREATH AND HAS NO ANGINAL SYMPTOMS. HE HAS A 30 PACK-YEAR HISTORY OF SMOKING BUT STOPPED SMOKING 10 YEARS AGO AND DOES NOT DRINK ALCOHOL. HIS PULSE IS 59/MIN, AND HIS BLOOD PRESSURE IS 135/75 MM HG. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION REVEALS 1+ LOWER EXTREMITY EDEMA. CARDIAC AND PULMONARY AUSCULTATION SHOW NO ABNORMALITIES. THERE IS NO LYMPHADENOPATHY. HIS LABORATORY STUDIES SHOW A HEMOGLOBIN OF 13.2 G/DL AND SERUM PROTEIN OF 10.1 G/DL. ECG SHOWS KNOWN Q WAVE ABNORMALITIES UNCHANGED SINCE THE LAST ECG ONE YEAR AGO. A SERUM PROTEIN ELECTROPHORESIS WITH IMMUNOFIXATION IS SHOWN.
question: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS THE MOST APPROPRIATE NEXT STEP TO ESTABLISH THE DIAGNOSIS?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I have occasional lower back pain.
How long have you been experiencing this lower back pain?
I've been experiencing this lower back pain for the last couple of years.
Have you noticed any other symptoms accompanying the back pain, such as fatigue, night sweats, or unintended weight loss?
No, I haven't noticed any other symptoms like fatigue, night sweats, or unintended weight loss accompanying the back pain.
Do you have any history of cancer in your family, particularly any types related to bone or blood?
I'm just a patient here for a check-up, and I have not mentioned any family history of cancer or specific illnesses in our discussion.
Are you currently taking any medications or have you had any recent injuries that might explain the lower back pain?
No, I'm not taking any medications or have had any recent injuries that might explain the lower back pain.
Have you experienced any changes in bowel or bladder function, or numbness or tingling in your legs?
No, I have not experienced any changes in bowel or bladder function, or numbness or tingling in my legs.
Final Diagnosis: Chronic lower back pain

Hello! I'm not really facing any specific symptoms today; I generally feel well.
That’s good to hear! Do you have any other medical conditions or concerns that brought you in today?
I've had occasional lower back pain in the last couple of years, but no other major concerns today.

No, I haven't experienced any weight changes, night sweats, or fevers recently.

I am a 71-year-old man.

No, I haven't noticed any changes in my bowel habits or blood in my stool.
Do you have a family history of any cancers or hematological diseases?
I'm sorry, I don't have any knowledge about my family history regarding cancers or hematological diseases.
Have you had any blood tests recently, and if so, were there any abnormalities noted?
Yes, I had some blood tests, and they showed that my hemoglobin is 13.2 g/dL and my serum protein is 10.1 g/dL.

Given your age, the elevated serum protein levels, and your occasional lower back pain, have you had any further investigations or specific tests, like serum protein electrophoresis, to evaluate the cause of the high protein levels?
Yes, I had a serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation as part of my tests.
What were the results of the serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation?
The results of the serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation were displayed, but I don’t know the specific details of those results.

No, I haven't experienced any bone pain or unusual fractures.
Final Diagnosis: Multiple Myeloma.
